markdownRemark.html:
So I’ve been using my https://vcolavin.wordpress.com/ since https://vcolavin.wordpress.com/2012/08/18/a-blueprint/, which is seven years ago at the time of this writing. For my personal work, I tend to value stability over almost anything else, and I didn’t see any need to switch to anything flashier. I’m not hating on people who ride the bleeding edge, but it tends not to be my personal preference.

I want to find what works for me and get good at it much more than I want to become a jack of all trades. This is analagous to how I slowly morphed from a full-stack to a front-end dev over the past year or two.

So I started my Wordpress blog in college, and I kept it through a significant chunk of my professional career.

I didn’t come at Wordpress from a tech background. I’ve had various blogs and journals since I was in middle school. I started vcolavin.wordpress.com in college, well before I was programming seriously.

Basically, I settled on Wordpress because of its dead-simplicity as a blogging platform, but it offered a lot of things I didn’t care for: analytics, comments, accounts, SEO. Almost everything aside from its

I am switching because I want tighter control of my personal brand without having to invest more in Wordpress and its environment. Before settling on Gatsby, I spent a day or two setting up Jekyll.

The feature of Wordpress I will miss the most is draft posts.

frontmatter.title: Switching to Gatsby
frontmatter.description: I'm still learning this new blog platform so bear with me please.
